title: Doubtful Fruit From Young Trees inside vs. outside the homeland
vignette: A produce-dealer ships fruit from abroad. In the homeland, must the buyer treat doubtful fruit from young trees as forbidden?

options.text: Forbid in the homeland; doubts are treated strictly there.
Permit; any doubt remains lenient as it is abroad.

title: Knowingly selling first-three-year fruit
vignette: A farmer’s orchard is in its third year. May he sell the fruit to recoup expenses?

options.text: Forbidden — no benefit may be derived from fruit from young trees at all.
Allowed if sold to a non-member; only community members are bound by the ban.

title: Overhanging branches across a border
vignette: Roots of the tree are in the homeland (year-three), but branches hang into Syria; a passer-by picks fruit in Syria.

options.text: Prohibit — status follows the root in the homeland.
Permit — status follows the place of picking.

title: Age-uncertain saplings
vignette: A buyer purchases a grove without records; trees might still be in the fruit from young trees period.

options.text: Assume forbidden until proven mature.
Assume permitted unless proven otherwise.

title: Fruit From Young Trees mixed into a large batch
vignette: One basket of fruit from young trees figs falls into 300 identical baskets.

options.text: Destroy them all — no nullification for rules about items with special status.
Permit if ratio ≥ 1:200; the fruit from young trees is nullified.

title: Using Fruit From Young Trees shells for fuel
vignette: A baker wants to burn fruit from young trees nut-shells in his oven.

options.text: Prohibit any benefit from their heat.
Permit after burning; ashes lose forbidden status.

title: Dyeing cloth with Fruit From Young Trees husks
vignette: A dyer boils fruit from young trees husks for pigment; may the finished garment be sold?

options.text: Garment remains forbidden — benefit continues.
Garment permitted — colour is intangible; benefit ended.

title: Feeding Fruit From Young Trees fruit to livestock
vignette: A farmer considers giving fruit from young trees dates to his animals.

options.text: Forbidden — feeding one’s animals is also personal benefit.
Permitted — only direct human use is banned.

title: Status of ashes after burning Fruit From Young Trees wood
vignette: After fruit from young trees logs are burned to ash, may the ash be used as fertilizer?

options.text: Yes; prohibition ends once reduced to ash.
No; even residual benefit is barred.

title: Retroactive nullification by dilution
vignette: Permitted wine is later added to a mixture that contains some fruit from young trees wine < 1:200. Does the new addition ‘fix’ the ratio?

options.text: Yes; later dilution retroactively nullifies the fruit from young trees.
No; mixture was forbidden the moment it formed.
